During the cushioning process of the lower limbs, such as when landing from a jump, the knee bends, which reduces the distance between the knee and hip joint to absorb impact and provide stability.
When the lower limbs are buffering, the knees bend, which reduces the distance between the knee and ankle as the leg compresses.

During the cushioning process of the lower limbs, such as when landing from a jump, the joints flex to absorb impact. This flexion decreases the distance between the ankle and the hip joint as the body lowers itself.
During takeoff in diving, the diver typically pushes off the diving board with their toes to maximize control and precision in their jump.

When standing on tiptoes, the heel is raised significantly off the ground, making the distance from the heel to the ground greater than the distance from the toes to the ground, which remains minimal or zero.

When standing on tiptoes, the heel is raised off the ground, making the distance from the heel to the ground greater than the distance from the center of the sole to the ground, which is in contact with the surface.

When standing on tiptoes, the heel is raised, increasing the distance from the center of the foot sole to the ground compared to the distance from the toes to the ground, which remains minimal. Therefore, the distance from the center of the foot sole to the ground is greater.

The distance between the knee and ankle is determined by the length of the bones in the lower limb, which does not change when extending the limbs. Therefore, the distance remains essentially unchanged.
When extending the lower limbs, the legs straighten, which increases the distance between the knees and the buttocks.
During a jump, the tip of the foot is usually higher than the heel as the foot points downward to generate force and propel the body upward.
When jumping off on one foot, the toe of the jumping foot is usually lower than the heel as the foot pushes off the ground, propelling the body upward.
During the whipping motion of the lower limb, the distance between the ankle and knee initially decreases as the leg bends, and then increases as the leg extends again.
During the lower limb whipping motion, the knee moves closer to the hip as the leg flexes, causing the distance between the knee and the hip to decrease.
When a person rotates their upper body to the left, their right shoulder naturally moves forward due to the mechanics of body rotation.
When a person rotates their upper body to the right, their left shoulder naturally moves forward as part of the rotational movement.
When a person rotates their upper body to the left, their right shoulder naturally moves further back due to the twisting motion of the torso.
When a person rotates their upper body to the right, their left shoulder naturally moves further back as part of the rotational movement.
When a person turns to the right while seated, their right shoulder typically moves forward as part of the natural body movement associated with turning in that direction.
When a person turns to the left while seated, their left shoulder naturally moves forward as part of the body's rotation in that direction.
When a person turns to the right while seated, their torso rotates, causing the left shoulder to move further back relative to the right shoulder.
When a person seated turns to the left, their torso rotates, causing the right shoulder to move further back relative to the left shoulder.
